Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale investigation of biomolecular force transduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Deborah Leckband of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Professor Leckband's research addresses the fundamental molecular mechanisms that enable cells to sense and propagate mechanical information between cells in tissues. The cells of all multicellular organisms are held together by molecular "Velcro", and cadherins are the principal protein components thereof. A protein, alpha-catenin, which is associated with cadherins is thought to act as a biomolecular force sensor, which activates molecular signaling processes in proportion to mechanical forces exerted on cadherin bonds at the cell surface. In this role, alpha-catenin functions as a nanomachine that converts mechanical force into biochemical signals, in order to regulate cell functions. Professor Leckband's program will investigate the mechanism by which alpha-catenin senses mechanical force using techniques including surface plasmon resonance and single molecule AFM (atomic force microscopy).

Because alpha-catenin is representative of a broader class of scaffolding proteins that control the mechano-chemical homeostasis of cells, the broader scientific impact of the work may be quite far-reaching. As important, this program will engage middle school girls interested in science and engineering through outreach activities at the University of Illinois. It will also provide education and multi-disciplinary training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. In this way, Prof. Leckband aspires to spark young scientists' curiosity and deepen their passion for and commitment to science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Findings from this study revealed novel molecular-scale design criteria for force transducers in living cells. The intellectual merit of this research is the determination of a molecular mechanism that enables cells to sense mechanical forces at adhesive contacts with other cells, in all tissues. Specifically, these studies identified structural features in a force transducing protein, alpha catenin that control how force activates the exposure of a functionally important site, to trigger biochemical subsequent changes in the cell—a process referred to as ‘force transduction’. The intellectual merit of this research is also the unique multidisciplinary effort, which involved collaborations with cell biologists, developmental biologists, structural biologists, and computational chemists, in the US and abroad.

Enabled by the crystal structure of alpha catenin determined by our collaborator, we initiated molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with a computational biochemist, in order to determine how force causes structural changes in alpha catenin during the force-transduction process. Our first breakthrough was based on atomistic simulations that identified key structural features within the alpha catenin structure that control its flexibility and the level of force needed to activate the protein.  These results motivated us to generate several alpha catenin mutants, in order to test several predictions of the simulations.  It also inspired our collaborators to determine whether similar mutations affect developmental processes in Drosophila (fruit fly) embryos. Our experimental studies tested how the mutations alter the ligand-binding and force-transduction functions of the protein, in solution binding measurements (in vitro) and in living cells. The results confirmed that key structural features or physical interactions identified in the simulations indeed control alpha catenin conformation switching in cells. Our collaborators further identified similar alpha catenin mutations that perturb embryogenesis in fly embryos. We verified that those mutations also affect alpha catenin force-transduction, using our approaches. The intellectual merit of this work is the identification of key structural elements in alpha catenin that control force transduction, both in vitro and in vivo. These results thus link atomistic stimulations of alpha catenin activation to its force transducing role, not only in cells but also in the embryonic development of a living organism.

In collaboration with the structural biology team, we also determined how an additional feature in alpha catenin regulates how it binds to the actin scaffolding in cells. This actin binding function is required to stabilize adhesion between cells in tissues. How a specific ‘actin binding’ region of alpha catenin linked to actin had been a puzzle. We conducted simulations with crystal structure data provided by the structural biology team. Importantly, our findings appear to explain why one alpha catenin mutant binds actin better than the native protein. The results also appear to explain why increasing the force on alpha catenin may strengthen its bond to actin, to generate a special type of ‘catch bond’. The intellectual merit of this work is the identification of the mechanistic significance of the alpha catenin structure that control its binding to actin as well as the conformational changes that occur in response to increased force on the molecule.

These findings impact a range of disciplines. The results provide new insight into how alpha catenin functions in cells and mutations may contribute to diseases such as cancer. These results advance our understanding of the physical chemistry of molecular force transduction, but they are already impacting researchers in structural biology and in developmental biology. This research also identified physical-chemical design rules that could guide the fabrication of abiotic, force-transducing nano machines. Beyond the scientific discoveries, this grant supported, in full or in part, the training of five graduate students in science and engineering disciplines, and one undergraduate chemistry student.  Outreach activities enabled by this grant further exposed elementary and middle-school girls to advances in science and engineering, as well as to exciting potential career paths.
